During the time he has worked he has become well known and his business is always received well in the zone, as his meat is very well regarded by his neighbours. Santos wants to acquire more animals to fatten and sell, and in this way plans to amplify his business and obtain better earnings. To achieve this, for the first time he is seeking a loan of 800 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa. Santos is a very responsible person and very hard-working. His biggest desire is to be able to offer his parents a better quality of life. In the zone where he lives he is very well known and well regarded by his neighbours.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pigs

loans.name: Mirador De Matilde Group

texts.es:
Esta foto fue tomada en la casa de la Sra. María Alicia F. que es el lugar en donde se realizan las reuniones semanales, como podemos observar en la foto están las 12 integrantes que forman el grupo denominado “Mirador de Matilde” haciendo alarde a su ubicación en el estado de Hidalgo.
Ella es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos los cuales trabajan y le ayudan con algunos de los gastos de los servicios de su casa, se dedica a la venta de pollo, requiere del crédito para invertir en la compra de una nueva bascula ya que la que tiene no sirve muy bien, al igual desea pintar su negocio para que luzca lo mejor posible. Nos comenta que trabaja de lunes a sábados arduamente con el afán de crear un ahorro para cuando ya no tenga las fuerzas necesarias para trabajar, pero por el momento disfruta mucho de su negocio y lo que más le agrada es el trato con sus clientas.

La tesorera del grupo es la Sra. Martha Silvia N. que se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza por catalogo desde hace 8 años, vive en unión libre, tiene dos hijos de 24 y 13 años de edad,  ella obtuvo su crédito para poder invertir en una mayor cantidad de productos ya que lo compra a un precio más económico y así poder obtener una mayor ganancia, cuenta con una gran número de clientes esto debido a los años de  experiencia en la venta de estos productos. 

Las integrantes de este grupo son mujeres trabajadoras y emprendedoras, la Sra. Gizeh G., por ejemplo, de 24 años de edad y con un hijo de 5 años, es casada y se dedica a la venta de regalos, ella obtuvo su crédito para invertir en material para decorar los regalos que le llevan para envolver y también para comprar los cristales de su mostrador los cuales algunos ya estaban rotos, en este momento es lo que necesita en su negocio para poder obtener un poco más de ganancia. Considera que el éxito es el resultado del trabajo de cada día, y le gustaría ver que su negocio crezca de manera importante porque sabe que con ello les podrá ofrecer una mejor  vida su pequeño hijo.
texts.en:
This photo was taken in the home of Maria Alicia F., which is where the group meets weekly. As we can see in the photo, there are 12 members in the group named Mirador de Matilde, to showcase their location in the state of Hidalgo. Maria Alicia is a single mother of two children, who work and help her with some of the household expenses. She sells chicken and is requesting this loan to invest in a new scale, because the one she has does not work well. She also wants to paint her business so that it will look its best. She mentions that she works very hard, Monday to Saturday, with the aim of saving up for when she is no longer able to work. However, for now she greatly enjoys her business and the most gratifying element is her rapport with her customers. The group's treasurer is Martha Silvia F., who has sold beauty products through a catalogue for 8 years. She is in a common-law marriage and has two children ages 24 and 13. She is requesting this loan to invest in a larger inventory which she will buy at a lower price and thus be able to make more profit. She has a large number of customers thanks to her years of experience selling these products. The group members are hard-working and enterprising women; Gizeh B., for example, is 24, married and has a 5-year-old child. She sells gifts and will invest her credit in material to decorate the gifts she wraps, and to buy glass for her display case, since some of the panes are broken. At this moment, this is what she needs for her business in order to earn a little bit more. She believes that success is the result of daily work, and she would like to see her business grow significantly because she knows that with it she will be able to offer her little child a better life. The other group members are: Elvira Hernández Ramírez Quilt sales Yadira Martínez D. J. Bag sales María Judith O. R. Electrical equipment sales Ma. Dolores M. Juárez Footwear sales Mónica Elvira O. Z. Fuller cosmetics sales Carmela P. F. Craft sales Judith R. P. Clothing sales Sarai R. P. Quilt sales Gloria Velázquez A. Candy sales

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a new scale, giftwrap, etc

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en: Mrs. Pheap T., 42 years old, is a villager who lives in Ta Vong village, Takeo province. She is a pig breeder while her husband, Mr. Noeun Bun, is a motorbike and bicycle repairer at home. With both businesses, they earn a small income to support the family. To support both businesses, Mrs. Pheap T. decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and pig food for breeding and to purchase motorbike and bicycle supplies to support her husband's business. This couple has five children; one is a construction worker, one is a congee seller, and one is a bicycle repairer. The other two are students in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy piglets, pig food and motorbike/bicycle supplies

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita G. is from the village of Taraka, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old. Rita is single and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Rita owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing manicure, pedicure, hair relax, haircut and other beauty parlor  services in the local community. Rita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from GDMPC. Rita is requesting a new loan of 40000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Rita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed for her beauty parlor services

loans.name: Saoreoun

texts.en: Mrs. Saoreoun M. is a 27-year-old married woman and a villager who lives in Ampil Kaeut village, Takeo province. She is a silk weaver at home and her husband, Mr. Chhan Chhoeun, is a pig middleman who owns a motorbike to support his business. With both businesses, they earn a small income to support their family. To help her husband's business, Mrs. Saoreoun M. decided to ask for a loan to buy more pigs. This couple has two children; one is a student and one is two years old. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy more pigs

loans.name: Mrs. Morm Sek Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of eight people located in Lech Mouy village in Kandal province. Each member of this village bank will use the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses. Mrs. Morm S. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. She is a farmer who rents a small piece of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. Now her problem is that her field is ready to plant but she does not have enough money to support it. So to improve production, Mrs. Morm S. is requesting a loan to do farming this current year. Her husband, Mr. Chhieng Choem, is soldier who earns a small salary to support his family. With these activities, they support a child who is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To do farming

loans.name: Audy

texts.en:
Audy S. is from the village of Calaran, in Calamba Misamis,  Occidental. He is 55 years old. Audy is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Audy owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soft drinks , soap & toothpaste in the local community. Audy has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Audy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Audy is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Audy from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Leoncio

texts.en:
Leoncio D. is from the village of Unidos Calamba Misamis Occidental. He is 54 years old. Leoncio is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Leoncio owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as cooking oil, salt,shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Leoncio has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leoncio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leoncio is requesting a new loan of 3000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leoncio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita T. is from the village of Calaran Calamba Misamis Occidental. She is 63 years old. Anita is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling vital plus products in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 13000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Anita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Anita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Channat's Group

texts.en: Four people make up a group loan located in Sleng Kong village in Kandal province. Mrs. Channat H. is the group leader, selected by the other members. Each member will use the loan for different purposes. She owns a general store at her home where she can earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. So to improve her business, Mrs. Channat H. is asking for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. Her husband, Mr. Samnag Noun, is a farmer who owns one hectare of land to cultivate rice to support his family. Through this activity, the couple supports three children. One of the children is enrolled in the local public school, while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell

loans.name: Elsa's Group

texts.en:
Elsa Torre, from the village of Sinian Baliangao Misamis Occidental, is the 49-year-old leader of a three-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member receives an individual loan, they are all responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Shine.

Elsa, who is married and has two adult-aged children, owns and operates a specialized retail store selling daily use products such as sugar, rice, salt, canned goods, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elsa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida D. is from the village of Boyogon, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old. Aida is widowed and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Aida owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, operating a specialized retail store business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from the buying and selling of copra in the local community. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Aida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase more copra and as additional working capital. Aida is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Aida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente S. is from the village of Sta. Ines. He is 42 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Vicente owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Vicente has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Vicente joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Vicente is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be his fifth from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his children's education.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Meu's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Meu N. is a group leader who has been selected by four other members of her group. This group loan is located in Prasat village in Kandal province. Each member will use the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses in the future. Mrs. Meu N. is a widow with a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. She is a farmer who owns a half-hectare of land to cultivate rice to support her family and to sell. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. So to improve her business, Mrs. Meu N. is asking for a loan to buy more rice to resell.

loans.use: To buy more rice to resell

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma G. is from the village of Barangay 17, Gundaya, Gingoog City. She is 29 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making snacks and other delicacies and selling them in the local community through peddling. Emma has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Emma joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional materials, such as plastic containers and ingredients needed to make the snack food, and was also used as working capital. Emma is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make more snack food for sale. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Vanny's Group

texts.en: In Spean Daek village in Kandal province, there are four people who make up a group loan. Mrs. Vanny H. is the group leader, selected by the other members. Each member will use the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who rents a plot of land to grow crops to sell to support her family.  She is a widow with six children. One of the children is a motorbike repairer, one is grocery seller in the local village, and the others are studying in the local public school. Since her child’s business is going, well she wants to expand it. So to improve this business, Mrs. Vanny H. is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to resell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resell

loans.name: Diosdado

texts.en:
Diosdado is from the village of Brgy.Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya.  He is 58 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Diosdado provides transportation services, by using a motorcycle. He has been in business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Diosdado joined ASKI to access financial services to improve his living situation and to engage in business activities.  He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from ASKI to purchase tires and other accessories.  Diosdado is requesting a new loan of 14000 PHP to repair his motorcycle. This loan will be his seventh from ASKI.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of his family. 

-----------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Limford T. is from the village of Malinao, Gingoog City. He is 42 years old. Limford is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Limford owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to transport passengers around the local community. Limford has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Limford joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Limford has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Limford is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools and materials for the maintenance of his motorcycle. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Limford from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools and materials for motorcycle maintenance

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
Dominga G. is from the village of San Antonio. She is 51 years old. Dominga is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Dominga owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Dominga has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 18,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Dominga joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dominga has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Dominga is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Dominga from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli P. is from the village of Damayuhan, Magsaysay, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental. She is 51 years old. Arceli is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Arceli owns & operates a business venture whose main source of income comes from selling bananas and coconuts in the local community. Arceli has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Arceli joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arceli has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase motor for the pump boat of her husband who is engaged in traditional fishing. Arceli is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to buy more raw bananas and coconuts to sell. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Arceli from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to renovate their house.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy bananas and coconuts for resale

loans.name: Thol

texts.en:
Mrs. Thol  C. is 30 years old and lives in Roluos village in Takeo province. She is farmer who owns 1.50 hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. 

To supporting her farm crop, Mrs. Thol  C. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer, pesticide, and rice seed, and to pay a laborer to plow her farm. 

Her husband, Mr. Mom Toem, is a construction worker and also a farming laborer so he can receive a small salary to support his family. This couple has three children, who all are students in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pesticide, and rice seed, and to pay a laborer to plow her farm

loans.name: Holishon's Group

texts.en:
Holishon S. is the leader of the group. She is 51 and a widow. She has raised a 23-year-old daughter. The daughter helps her mom with housework. Holishon's husband died three years ago, and after that, she had to start to do something to earn money. She started to breed cattle, poultry and cultivate fruit and vegetables. The initial investment in this business activity was 8000 soms ($174.17) and now she makes 2100 soms ($45.72) per month. Holishon applied for the loan, because she needs money to purchase a calf for fattening and breeding. In the future she wants to save some money to contribute to her daughter's wedding.

Shohsanam V. is the treasurer of the group. She is 25 and a widow. Shohsanam lives with her parents. In order to make money, Shohsanam works in a pharmacy and her parents breed cattle and cultivate fruit and vegetables.  Shohsanam's parents started that activity 21 year ago, with the initial investment of 2100 soms ($45.72). In this way they make 2700 soms ($58.78) per month. That profit made them able to build a new house, contribute some money to their older son's and older daughter's weddings. With money received from the loan, Shohsanam wants to purchase a cow for fattening and breeding. 

Munosibzhon M. is 25. He lives with his parents. The father works as a driver, the older sister works in a pharmacy, and the brother went off to work in Russia to make some money. Four years ago with the initial investment of 2700 soms ($58.78) Munosibzhon started wholesaling potatoes. Now he wholesales fruit and vegetables, particularly cherries. In this way he earns 6000 soms ($130.63) per month. Munosibzhon wants to get a loan to purchase a variety of fruits and vegetables in order to sell them in Bishkek and make good money. In the future he wants to build a new house and buy a vehicle. 

Dilbarhon M. is 27. Her husband works as a builder. They have a son and two daughters. Four years ago with an initial investment of 7800 soms ($169.82) Dilbarhon started to breed cattle and cultivate different sorts of fruit and vegetables. In this way she makes 1800 soms ($39.19) per month. Now she wants to get a loan to purchase a bull-calf for fattening in order to sell it later on.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: to purchase a calf for breeding

loans.name: Ya

texts.en:
Mrs. Ya N. is 58 years old and lives in Roluos village, Takeo province. She is farmer who owns 1 hectare of land to cultivate rice for a living. 

In order to increase her income in order to improve her family's standard of living and support her farming, Mrs. Ya N. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She will use the rest of the loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to support her farming. 

Mrs. Ya N. is a widow with two children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the younger one is a student.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding, as well as fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Min

texts.en:
Mrs. Min S. is a 27-year-old married woman who lives in Preal village in Takeo province. She is a farmer and also breeds pig at home, while her husband, Mr. Phirun Eang, breeds ducks for eggs. With their businesses, they earn a small income to support their family. 

To support these businesses, Mrs. Min S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to support her farming; duck food for the duck breeding business; and piglets and pig food for pig breeding. 

This couple has three children; one is attending in the local school while the other two are two young to study or work. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, duck food, and piglets and pig food

loans.name: Khorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Khorn S. is 38 years old and lives in Thkov village, Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1 hectare of land to cultivate rice. She is also cake seller who earns a small income to support her family. 

In order to increase her income to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Khorn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. 

Mrs. Khorn S. is a widow with three children: one drives a car for a salary; one is a security guard; and the youngest child is a year old.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Norn

texts.en: Mrs. Norn N., age 38, lives in Choes Village, Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns 1-hectare (~2.5 acres) of land on which she grows rice. She also breeds pigs at home. To support her pig business, Mrs. Norn N. decided to ask for a loan to buy ten piglets and pig food. Her husband, Mr. Vann Thars, is a wine-maker and also makes palm sugar to sell. With the all business, they can earn a small income to support their family. This couple has four children who all are students and also support their parent's businesses.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets and pig food

loans.name: Elida

texts.en:
Elida B. is from the village of Mimbunga, Gingoog City. She is 35 years old. Elida is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Elida owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of daily use products in the local community. Elida has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000  PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Elida is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Elida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Vannak's Group

texts.en:
This loan group consists of four people who live in Chan Lork Village in Kandal Province. Each member will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose, but all will use it to improve their businesses. 

Mr. Vannak N. has been selected by the other members to be the group leader. He is twenty years old. He is a construction worker and his wife, Mrs. Pharey Yos, is a seamstress in garment factory. His work place is far away from his house, so, to improve the condition of his family, Mr. Vannak N. is seeking a loan to buy a new motorbike for transportation. The couple supports a child who is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike for transportation

loans.name: Baktygul's Group

texts.en:
Baktygul N. is the leader of the group, and she is 39. Her husband works as a builder. They have a daughter and a son. The daughter is fifteen; she studies at school in the 8th class and the son works as a handyman in a store. The son and the husband also breed cattle to make money. With money received from the loan, Baktygul wants to purchase three farm animals for breeding. In the future she plans to increase the number of livestock and improve their living conditions.

Shaiyrkul S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 55 and a widow. She has raised a daughter and two sons. The daughter is married, the older son went to Russia to make some money, and the younger son helps his mom around the farm. Shaiyrkul has been breeding cattle for 20 years, if she needs money she can sell some cattle. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase one farm animal in order to increase the number of livestock.

Shapanbubu I. is 57 and her husband is a pensioner. They have three sons and six daughters. The older children are married and live separately with their families. The younger son and the younger daughter study at school.  Shapanbubu and her husband have been farming for 16 years, since 1994. Now she applied for the loan because she needs money to pay for tractor service, to purchase 50 litters of fuel, which is needed for the sowing process, and buy some cattle for breeding. 

Turumkan K. is 58 and married. She has four sons and two daughters. All the children are married and live separately with their families. Three years ago Turumkan and her husband sold cattle for 15000 soms ($326.58), and with that amount they started to breed cattle and sell them later on. In this way they make 6000 soms ($130.63) per month. Now Turumkan wants to get a loan to purchase two cows to sell after fattening.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: to purchase three farm animals for breeding

loans.name: Aomara's Group

texts.en:
This loan group consists of four people who live in Steung Chrov Village in Kandal Province. Mrs. Aomara V. has been selected by the members to be the group leader. Each member of the group will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose. 

Mrs. Aomara V. is a healer who can earn some money to support her family. To improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Aomara V. is asking for a loan to buy various medicines to resell. Her husband, Mr. Chab Brang, is a policeman who can get a low salary to support his family. Through their work, the couple supports three children, one of whom is a policeman, one is employed by a private company, and the other attends the local public school.

loans.use: To buy various medicines to resell

loans.name: Taman Indah Group

texts.en:
I Ketut S. U.  is a 33-year-old man living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  I Ketut is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  

I Ketut is married and has 3 school-aged children.  To make a living, I Ketut owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  I Ketut has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 300,000 IDR a month from these activities.

In 2010, I Ketut joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  I Ketut is requesting from MUK his first loan of 1,375,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  I Ketut plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation, and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





I Ketut S. U. (0) merupakan 33 tahun pria.  Dia (laki-laki) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  I Ketut adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 10 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  0


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber U. penghasilan bisnis tersebut terU. berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  I Ketut sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 5 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, I Ketut menghasilkan sekitar 300,000 IDR.  Dalam 2010, I Ketut bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  I Ketut meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK.    Dia (laki-laki) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,375,000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Lolynia

texts.en:
Lolynia M. is from Gingoog  City. She is 54 years old. Lolynia is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Lolynia owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling ready-to-wear items like clothes in the local community. Lolynia has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lolynia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lolynia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Lolynia is requesting a new loan of 13,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Lolynia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Babi Rahayu Group

texts.en: Ni Ketut W. is a 46-year-old female living in the town of Melaya, Bali. She is the group leader of this fourteen-member group loan offered by MUK. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Babi Rahayu Group (PK-10151). Ni Ketut is married and has two adult children. She owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 100,000 IDR a month from these activities. In 2010, Ni Ketut joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 1,500,000 IDR which will be used to invest in expanding her business. The loan will be her first from MUK. Ni Ketut plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About MUK: The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives. ***************************************************** Ni Ketut W. (0) merupakan 46 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali. Ni Ketut adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 14 anggota. Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar. Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Babi Rahayu (PK-10151). Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Ketut sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 10 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Ketut menghasilkan sekitar 100,000 IDR. Dalam 2010, Ni Ketut bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Ketut meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,500,000 IDR. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK. Tentang MUK: Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta R. is from the village of Luano, Gingoog City. She is 37 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. While Julieta’s husband is engaged in a transportation business with their motorcycle, Julieta is engaged in a food business where she cooks and sells snack foods to the local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Julieta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to repair the motorcycle that is used in their trasportation business. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her snack-food business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Baktybubu's Group

texts.en: Baktybubu S. is the leader of this group. She is 50 and her husband works in the Ministry of Emergency Situations. They have a fifteen-year-old son who studies at school. Baktybubu works as a nurse in the hospital; she also sells convenience goods and breeds cattle. Seven years ago she obtained a loan of 7,000 soms (approximately 150 USD) and with that money she bought different goods and resold them. In this way she now earns 3,000 soms (approximately 65 USD) per month. She applied for this loan because she needs money to purchase consumer goods in order to resell them and make some profit. In the future she wants to increase the number of her cattle. Zhumash T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 52 and divorced. Her son is married; he helps Zhumash to sell clothes at the market. Fourteen years ago Zhumash sold vegetables and, with an initial investment of 3,000 soms, she started to sell clothes. In this way she earns 15,700 soms (approximately 340 USD) per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase a variety of clothes in order to increase the turnover of her business. Zamirbek S. is 30 and is married. He has three children: the older son studies at school in the 1st class; the other two are too young. Two years ago Zamirbek, with an initial investment of 14,000 soms (approximately 305 USD), bought cattle to raise. After fattening them he sells some cattle to make money. In this way he earns 5,000 soms (approximately 110 USD) per month. He also cultivates fruits and vegetables. Now he wants to obtain a loan to pay for tractor services, to fertilize his land, and to sow potatoes. In autumn he plans to sell potatoes to make money and buy some school clothes for his children. Nasip U. is 58 and is married. She has a daughter and a son; the son is married and lives separately with his family. Nasip and her husband have been breeding, fattening and selling livestock for ten years. They started with an initial investment of 7,000 soms and now they make 4,000 soms (approximately 85 USD) per month. With money received from the loan, Nasip wants to purchase one farm animal to increase the number of her livestock. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase consumer goods to sell

loans.name: Abundia

texts.en: Abundia L. is from the town of Banga. She is 54 years old, is married, and has two adult children. Abundia owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-four years. Abundia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Abundia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This loan will be her second from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Shakeb Andrabe Group

texts.en:
Belqis is the group leader of the Shakeb Andrabe Group. Belqis is 45 years old. She lives in Kabul. She is a bead worker and she has been involved in this business for more than 5 years. She wants to take a loan for her bead-working business. She wants to enlarge her business, she wants buy beads for her business, and she wants to expand and improve her business.

All of the group members would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business

loans.name: Edward

texts.en: Edward N. is from the village of Natugod, Medina, Misamis Oriental. He is 35 years old and is married. Edward owns and operates a specialized retail business, selling charcoal and firewood in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Edward joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP of which part will be used to purchase coconut shells that will be processed into charcoal, and part will be used as additional working capital. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. Edward plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase coconut shells that will be processed into charcoal, and as additional working capital

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna M. is from the village of Cabantian, Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 45 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. Myrna owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Myrna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Myrna plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Denia

texts.en:
Denia D. is from the town of Banga. She is 35 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children.

Denia owns and operates a business raising and selling "tilapia" (St. Peter's fish) to the market. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years already.

Denia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Denia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feeds and additional fish to sell. This loan will be her second from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To buy feeds and additional fish to sell

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina B. is from Gingoog City. She is 31 years old, is married, and has six adult children. Gina owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling vegetables in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Gina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding her business. Gina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en: 40-year-old Elsie B. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has five school-aged children. Elsie farms and also grows fish – her one-hectare (2.5-acre) land is divided into a rice field and a fish pond. She sells her harvest at the market and around her community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-one years already. In January 2010, Elsie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her second from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure and feeds

loans.name: Estela

texts.en:
Estela S. is from the town of Banga. She is 45 years old, is married, and has five school-aged children.

Estela owns a fish pond where she grows tilapia (St. Peter's fish) which she sells to the market. She also owns 2 hectares (5 acres) of coconut plantation. Estela shares that she is thankful for what she has and she hopes to succeed in all her ventures in life. She has been engaged in her business for more than twenty years now.

In 2010, Estela joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Estela is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be her second from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Kok

texts.en: Mr. Kok P. is 63 years old. He lives in Choes Village in Takeo Province. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he grows rice. To support his farm, Mr. Kok P. decided to request a loan to purchase a harvesting machine to improve his farm production. In addition to being a farmer, Mr. Kok P. also works as a farm laborer.  He earns a little salary which he uses to support his family. Mr. Kok P. is widower with four children; three are seamstresses in the garment factory and one drives a harvesting machine.

loans.use: To purchase a harvesting machine

loans.name: Vita

texts.en:
Vita C. is from the village of Alibago Enrile in Cagayan.  She is 33 years old, married and has two school-aged children.  To make a living, Vita owns and runs a general store. Her main source of income comes from selling daily use products like shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community.  Vita has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month.

Vita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Vita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI.  Now Vita is requesting a loan of 13000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell.  This loan will be her third from ASKI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

---------------------------------------
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Khemsan

texts.en: Mrs. Khemsan N. is a 30-year-old married woman and a villager who lives in Choes village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns one hectare of land to cultivate rice.  To help with the farming, Mrs. Khemsan N. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and to pay out for labor to plow her farm. Her husband, Mr. Vy Ngoy, is a sugar palm maker and a cow middleman who earns a small income to support his family. This couple has two children, who are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and have her farm plowed

loans.name: Marieta

Marieta is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the third loan taken out by Marieta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Vener

texts.en:
Vener V. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 46 years old. Vener is married and has four infant children. loans.name: Luch

texts.en: Mrs. Luch T. is 50 years old and a villager who lives in Kanlaeng Khla village in Takeo province.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living.  Aside from farming, she also makes baskets to sell to earn a small income to support her family. In order to increase her income to improve the family, Mrs. Luch T. decided to ask for a loan to buy two piglets for breeding. Mrs. Luch T. is a widow with two children; one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the other one is attending the local school.

loans.name: Mrs. Sophy Moch Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of nine people who are located in Preak CH. Prom village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sophy M. is a village bank president, selected by the other members who will use the loan for different purposes. She was born in 1986. She owns a general store at her home. Now her business is going well, so she wants to expand. So to improve her business, Mrs. Sophy M. is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to sell. Her husband, Mr. Chan Thoeurn Baun, is a driver. Through this activity, they support a child who is enrolled in local public school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: Née en 1973, A. Pauline est mariée à ASSOGBA Germain, un coiffeur. Pauline est mère de trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Mais deux autres enfants sont en plus à sa charge. Pauline vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants au quartier Sèkandji, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis huit ans environs. Pauline vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui, les différentes charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui apporte son activité. Pauline a fréquenté l’école et s’est arrêté au cours secondaire. Il y a près de cinq ans que Pauline s’est mise à vendre des ustensiles de cuisine (Plats, bols en séries, gobelets, glacières, cuillères, fourchettes, casseroles en séries, bassines, etc.) à Sèkandji. Pauline achète ses produits à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est la première fois que Pauline sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter le stock de ses produits.
texts.en:
Born in 1973, Pauline A. is married to Germain Assogba, a hairstylist. Pauline is the mother of three children, some of whom are in school. But she has two additional children in her care. Pauline has lived together with her husband and children in the Sèkandji area, in the Sèmè-Podji commune, for about eight years. She helps her husband and, with him, takes care of the various family expenses, thanks to the income provided by her business. Pauline attended school and stopped at the secondary level. About five years ago, she started selling kitchen utensils (plates, bowl sets, cups, iceboxes, spoons, forks, pans, basins, etc.) in Sèkandji. She buys her goods in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. This is the first time Pauline is seeking financial assistance through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), with the goal of strengthening her business and increasing her stock of merchandise.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kitchen utensils (plates, bowls, spoon sets, etc.)

loans.name: Vergie

texts.en:
Vergie U. is from the village of Malalinta. She is 45 years old. Vergie is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Vergie owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Vergie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately PHP 3,500 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Vergie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vergie has successfully repaid a previous loan of PHP 13,000 from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Vergie is requesting a new loan of PHP 10,000 which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Vergie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of the borrower's children.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Ruku

texts.en:
Mrs. Ruku H. lives in Sainbu-Bhaishapati, Lalitpur. It is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in seasonal farming. Mrs. H. lives with her husband and two sons. Her husband Mr. Kul Bahadur H. works in a private office. Her sons are studying in grades 12 and 8 respectively.

Mrs. H. is a wholesaler in the potato business. She sells potatoes cheaply in the local market. She buys potatoes from the Kalimati bazaar, which is one of the famous wholesale vegetable bazaars of the Kathmandu valley. 

She has already taken a second loan from Kiva and has cleared her loan. Now Mrs. H. is requesting a loan in the amount of 30000.00 Nepal rupees to buy potatoes for her business.

loans.use: To buy potatoes for her business

loans.name: Saroeurn's Group

texts.en:
Three people make up a group loan. They are located in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. Mrs. Saroeurn E., 38 years-old, has been selected as the leader of the group by the members. Each member of this group loan will use it to support a different purpose.

Mrs. Saroeurn E. is a farmer who owns 1.50 hectares of land to cultivate rice.  To support this farming, Mrs. Saroeurn E. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides and to pay for a water machine. Her husband, Mr. Set Chhoeng, is a fisherman and a construction worker who earn insufficient income to support his family. This couple has four children. One child is a farmer while the other three are students in the local school. Mrs. Sarrat P., is acting as a guarantor for the group.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides and to pay for a water machine.

loans.name: Phally's Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan In Dei Edth Kaoh Phos village in Kandal province consisting of five people who make up a group loan. All the members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes that can improve their businesses. 

Mrs. Phally Y. is the group leader as selected by the other members. She is 38 years-old.  She is a white wine maker and also breeds pigs. Her problem is that her pigsty is too old to use.  Therefore, Mrs. Phally Y. is applying for a loan to build a new pigsty. Her husband, Mr. Sovanareth Brach, is a government worker. From these activities, they support five children who are all attending local public school.

loans.use: To build a new pigsty.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Jealyn

texts.en:
Jealyn D., 26, is from the town of Banga. She is married and has two small children. She owns a half-hectare corn field and also runs a small  sari-sari (variety) store at her house. She also sells dry goods at the market together with her harvest of corn. Jealyn is a very active entrepreneur and has also started raising ducks. She hopes to maintain her businesses and keep balance in her family life.

Jealyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer for the corn field, feed for the ducks, and additional supplies for her store. This will be the second loan taken out by Jealyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Shanti

texts.en:
Mrs. Shanti C., a resident of Sainbu-Bhaishapati, lives in a single family home with her husband and one son. Her husband's name is Ram Kumar C. and he works in a private office. Her son is studying in pre-primary school.

Mrs. C. is a farmer in Sainbu-Bhaishapati. She grows different types of vegetables on her farm. Due to the lack of technology, most of the farmers in this area depend on seasonal farming. Nepal is an agricultural country, but new technology has not been introduced yet in farming. Therefore, the production of vegetables is not enough to feed the population of the country.

Mrs. C. sells her vegetables in the local vegetable market in the morning and the evening. She is requesting a loan of Rs 20000.00 to buy seeds and fertilizers for her work.

loans.use: To buys seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna D. V. is from the village of Malalinta. She is 38 years old, married and has two infant children. To make a living, Myrna owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,200 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Erian Y. is from the village of Malibud, Gingoog City. She is 27 years old and single. To make a living, Erian owns and oeprates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Erian has been in business for more than one year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Erian joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erian has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Erian is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which also will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Erian from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Mrs. Sophan Yet Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eight people located in Thmey village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Sophan Y. is the village bank president, selected by the other members who will each use part of the loan to buy something that can support their businesses. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land for growing crops to sell to support her family. She is also a pig breeder but her problem is that she does not have a place for her pig. So to improve her pig breeding, Mrs. Sophan Y. is applying for a loan to build a pigsty. Her husband, Mr. Thoeurn Phorn, is a fisherman. She is the mother of five children, one of whom is a security guard for a private company, another is a laborer and the remainder are studying at the local public school.

loans.use: To build a pigsty
