loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn D. is from the town of Banga. She is 49 years old, married and has a 24-year-old child. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a fishing business, raising and selling "tilapia" (St. Peter's fish) at the market. She also sells dry goods at her town's market. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 20 years now.

Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase food for the fish and also additional stock for her dry goods. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jocelyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase food for fish and additional inventory of dry goods for sale at market

loans.name: Shanti Singh

texts.en:
Mrs. Shanti Singh T. lives in a single-family home with her husband and their son in Sainbu-Bhaishipati Lalitpur. Their son attends primary school.

Mrs. T. and her husband, Mr. Dhan Shyam T., have run their own grocery store for more than five years. Before this, Mr. T. had tried hard to find suitable employment; when his efforts proved unsuccessful, he decided that he and his wife should open their own grocery business. They sell different types of grocery items at their store such as rice, maize, noodles, and a variety of snacks.

Mrs. T. is requesting a loan of 25,000 NPR to buy different varieties of grocery goods. Her primary aim is to provide a better education for her son.

loans.use: To buys grocery goods

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr: Née le 05 Juillet 1971, B. Véronique est mariée à FONTECLOUNON Cyrille, un carreleur. Le couple a trois enfants, qui sont toujours à leur charge, et dont certains sont scolarisés. Véronique vit depuis dix sept ans environs à PK10, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Véronique habite avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la famille. Véronique n’est pas allée à l’école. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Véronique mène comme activité, la vente de liqueurs, de bougies et divers autres produits (couscous, riz, petits pois, conserves de tomate, etc.) à Bahocon, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Véronique s’approvisionne. Véronique sollicite pour une deuxième fois, de crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et de rehausser le niveau de son activité, pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Le premier crédit que Véronique a reçu de ALIDé a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
Born on 5 July 1971, Véronique B. is married to Cyrille Fonteclounon, a tiler. The couple have three children, all of whom are still in their care, and some of whom are in school. Véronique has lived for about seven years in PK10, in the town of Sèmè-Podji. She lives with her children and husband. The couple share the various family expenses. Véronique did not attend school. For about ten years, she has run a business selling liquor, candles, and various other products (couscous, rice, peas, canned tomatoes, etc.) in Bahocon, in the town of Sèmè-Podji. Véronique gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is seeking her second loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), in order to increase her working capital and raise the level of her business to better satisfy her customers. The first loan Véronique received through ALIDÉ was repaid properly.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell liquor and food products (couscous, milk, peas, canned goods, etc.)

loans.name: Estrelita

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Estrelita has been engaged in her business for over 35 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

texts.en: Mrs. Lai T. is 55 years old and is a villager who lives in Boueng Kroam village, Kandal province. She was selected as the leader of a group loan by the group's six members. Each member of this group loan will use their part of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Lai T. is a farmer who owns one hectare of land on which to grow crops. She decided to ask for a loan for her farm to buy fertilizer, rice seed and corn seed to support her farming crops. Aside from being a farmer, she is also a congee (rice porridge) seller who earns a little income to support her family's living costs. Mrs. Lai T. is a widow with four children; one is a farmer who supports her with the farming and the other three are teachers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed and corn seed

Naneth has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Naneth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Joanne

texts.en:
At the age of 30, Joanne S. is now the mother of four infant children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Joanne has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever she sells an animal she has raised. Joanne said that it is difficult to have four very young children but she is doing her best to meet their needs. Joanne's family lives in the village of Alibago, Enrile, Cagayan. 

In 2009, Joanne joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. Joanne is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the third loan she has taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and north-eastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Chérifatou

texts.fr: Née en 1970 à Sakété, dans le département du Plateau, S. Chérifatou est mariée à AKANNI Aliou, un électricien bâtiment. Le couple a six enfants, tous scolarisés et vivant à leur charge. Chérifatou vit avec sa famille à PK11, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Chérifatou apporte une aide financière à son mari, en ce qui concerne les dépenses familiales. Chérifatou n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de quinze ans que Chérifatou vend divers produits (riz, pâtes alimentaires, sucre, lait, mayonnaise, nescafé, conserves de tomate et de sardines, bombons, bougies, savons, insecticides, sandalettes, etc.), ce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses besoins et aux besoins de sa famille. Chérifatou achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et les vend à son domicile. Chérifatou a bénéficié une fois déjà, de prêt à ALIDé, et a bien effectué le remboursement. Face aux exigences de sa clientèle, Chérifatou désire renforcer un peu plus son activité et mieux répondre à leurs différentes demandes. C’est en raison de cela que Chérifatou sollicite un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Sakété, in the Plateau department, Chérifatou S. is married to Aliou Akanni, a building electrician. The couple have six children, all in school and living under their parents' care. Chérifatou lives with her family in PK11, in the town of Sèmè-Podji. She helps her husband in financial matters related to the family's expenses. Chérifatou did not go to school. For about 15 years, she has been selling various goods (rice, pasta, sugar, milk, mayonnaise, Nescafé coffee, canned tomatoes and sardines, sweets, candles, soap, insecticides, sandals, etc.), which allows her to meet her needs and those of her family. Chérifatou buys her goods at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin, and sells them at her house. She has already benefited from one previous loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), and repaid it well. Faced with the demands of her customers, Chérifatou wants to strengthen her business a little more and respond to her clientele's various requests. It is for this reason that Chérifatou is seeking a second loan.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell various products (rice, pasta, sugar, milk, mayonnaise, canned tomatoes and sardines, soap, etc.)

loans.name: Heang's Group

Mrs. Heang C. and her husband, Mr. Naraen Pring, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate corn and beans. Aside from being a farmer, Mr. Naraen Pring is a fisherman who owns fishing equipment and a boat for his business. Mrs. Heang C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fishing supplies to support her husband's business. This couple has five children; four are students in the local school and also help with their parents' businesses while the youngest is one year old.

With the loan, all the members hope to increase their income to improve their family's living. Mrs. Sokha C. sells groceries to earn a small income to support her family's living. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business activities. Her husband, Mr. Chan Yin, is a farmer who owns a plot of land for growing crops. This couple has four children; three are seamstresses in the garment factory while the fourth is also a grocery seller who supports her business.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

So to improve production, Mrs. Sorn S. is asking for a loan to buy cane to grow and fertilizer; with the rest of the loan, she will rent a plow machine to plow her field. She is a widow with three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a waiter and the other does farming.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
It is now fifteen years ago that M. Frank started up his banana business in Nyamabare, Rukungiri district, in western Uganda. With this as his only source of livelihood, he has painstakingly managed to make ends meet, albeit with some long-drawn-out seasonal income fluctuations and high labour cost challenges.

With a hardwork ethic in tow, the 38-year-old married and happy-go-lucky father of one has kept his business on a consolidated growth path. In a month, Frank makes close to 645,000 Ugandan shillings. His business gaining ground over these years has, in effect, also meant that his family has benefited, especially in providing for their requirements.

Frank’s business plan of action for the future is to be able to sell more bananas to an increasingly expanding market. With this loan, Frank envisages purchasing manure and pesticides for his plantation.

loans.use: To purchase manure and pesticides for his plantation

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: A. Marie est née en 1976 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à AHOUMENOU Romuald, Marie est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Il y a environs dix sept ans que Marie s'est installée au quartier Kowégbo à Cotonou, où elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Marie vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les charges familiales, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Marie n'a jamais été à l'école. Marie vend des produits cosmétiques et des bijoux de façon ambulante. De façon secondaire, Marie vend des jus de bissap et des sucettes qu'elle conserve dans les glacières. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Marie achète ses produits. Marie exerce cette activité depuis sept ans environs et a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Marie désire développer un peu plus son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. C'est la raison pour laquelle Marie sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un quatrième prêt.
texts.en:
Marie Aïhoue was born in 1976 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Romuald Ahoumenou, Marie has four children, all in school. It has been about seventeen years since Marie moved to the Kowégbo area of Cotonou, where she lives with her husband and children. Marie helps her husband and, with him, provides for the family, thanks to the income from her business. Marie never attended school. She sells cosmetics and jewelry door-to-door. On the side, Marie sells roselle (hibiscus) juice and lollipops, which she keeps in ice boxes. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Marie has run this business for about seven years, and has already benefited from three loans through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), all of which where repaid properly. Marie wants to develop her business a little more and satisfy her clientele better. This is the reason why she is seeking a fourth loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell cosmetics and jewelry

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
K. Julius is very ambitious about owning a big agricultural farm in his home area in Kihani, Ibanda. He is in far cry narrow circumstances that may make him seem like a wishful thinker and this means he faces long odds in achieving that mission.

Julius, however, has at length built a strong attribute of determination that has played into his hands. With strong hardworking skills up his sleeve, he has gotten for his banana-selling business a dependable niche and has banked on this business for the last fifteen years. His family of five children has also enjoyed the good graces that have come with doing this business.

Monthly profits to the tune of 120,000 Ugandan shillings is what Julius has been getting since the beginning. With this loan he hopes to purchase mulches and fertilizers to help improve his plantation and also to buy pesticides as pests like banana weevils have always affected the plantation, hence reducing his yields.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides, mulches and fertilizers for his plantation

loans.name: Apasara

texts.en:
Apasara T. has one son and one daughter. Her son is studying in grade 12 and her daughter is in grade 8. Both Mrs. T. and her husband Mr. Sailendra T. are engaged in a cow-raising business.They already own one cow and they have been selling milk in their area. In Nepal pure and fresh cow’s milk is highly valued for human nutrition. They live in Sainbu-Bhaishapati and in that area the demand for milk is constantly increasing.

They carry their milk containers and sell door-to-door daily in the morning and in the evening.  Because of the rising demand for milk, they want to buy another cow to increase their production.  So  Mrs. Apasara plans to use her loan to purchase a jersey cow which produces more milk than normal cows.

loans.use: to buy a young cow

loans.name: Marcelinda

texts.en:
Marcelinda T. is from the village of  Talon, Gingoog City. She is 60 years old. Marcelinda is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Marcelinda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Marcelinda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marcelinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcelinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marcelinda is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 11th loan taken out by Marcelinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Kulai's Group

texts.en:
Kulai A., 58, is the leader of the group. Her husband is retired. She has a son and two daughters. Her son works as a welder and the daughters own a private sewing workshop. Sometimes they send pieces of material that are left over after production and Kulai makes traditional clothes and accessories. In this way she makes 1500 soms ($32.65) per month. Kulai and her husband also breed livestock. With money received from the loan, she will purchase 30 chickens and two other farm animals in order to increase the number of livestock. In the future Kulai plans to buy a kiosk and sell convenience goods.

Toktogul M. is 63. His wife is retired. They have a grandchild who studies at school. Toktogul and his wife have been breeding livestock for a long time. When necessary, they sell livestock to make money. In this way they make 2000 soms ($43.54) per month. Toktogul applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase cattle for breeding.

Mairmakan K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 61 and married. They have two sons, who fish to earn money. Six years ago, with the initial investment of 500 soms ($10.88), Mairamkan began to take orders and sew traditional clothes. In this way she earns 1500 soms ($32.65) per month. That profit made her able to purchase cattle for 18000 soms ($391.90). Mairamkan needs a loan to purchase one cow and two other farm animals. In the future she wants to expand the business and export her products to Kazakhstan.

Kanymbubu I. is 60. Her husband is retired. Their grandchild lives with them; he is thirteen and attends school. Kanymbubu and her husband have been breeding cattle and cultivating different fruits and vegetables for about 40 years. Selling fruits and vegetables they make 2000 soms ($43.54) per month. Kanymbubu applied for the loan, because she needs money to pay for tractor services and purchase fuel, which is needed for the sowing process in the summer season.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: to purchase 30 chickens and two other farm animals

loans.name: Mrs. Vanny Chhurn Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Vanny C. is a village bank president who has been selected by sixteen people who are located in Sampan Leu village in Kandal province. All the members will use a piece of the loan to do something that can improve their business in the future. Mrs. Vanny C. was born in 1953. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land for cultivating rice to support her family. Now her problem is that her field has infertile soil. To improve production, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, and rest of the loan she will use to buy cane for growing. She is widow with a child who is a farmer, too.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: May Grace

texts.en:
May Grace S. is from the village of Barandias, Pangantucan Bukidnon. She is 23 years old. May Grace is married and has 1 infant. To make a living, May Grace owns & operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling gasoline (by the liter) in the local community. May Grace has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, May Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. May Grace has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. May Grace is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by May Grace from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Kimhong's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Mouylen L. is 37 years old and is the leader of group loan who was selected by the group which consists of four members, located in Preak Raing village, Kandal province. Each member of this group loan will use it to support their different purposes. Mrs. Mouylen L. is a grocery seller who owns a small store at home to support her family. For her grocery business, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to enlarge her business activities. She and her husband have a child who is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Robert Leonard

texts.en:
Robert Leonard G. is from the village named Barangay Roxas, in Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 27 years old and single. To make a living, he owns and operates a  specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling electronic products in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over eight years and earns approximately $390 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Robert Leonard joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand his product offering

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en:
Elmer D. is from the village of  Talon, Gingoog City. He is 40 years old. Elmer is single. To make a living, Elmer owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to transport  passengers local community. Elmer has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Elmer joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elmer has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Elmer is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the 11th loan taken out by Elmer from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Simone

texts.fr: A. Simone est née en 1973 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à GBEDEY William, Simone est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Simone vit depuis une douzaine d'année au quartier Irédé à Cotonou, avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Simone n'a pas été à l'école. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Simone prépare et vend de la nourriture (aliment local fait à base de maïs, accompagné de sauce) à Cotonou. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Simone fait ses provisions. Simone exerce cette activité depuis quatorze ans et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Simone  a bien effectué les remboursements desdits crédits. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Simone sollicite un troisième prêt, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de  sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Simone A. was born in 1973 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to William Gbedey, she has four children who are all in school. Simone has lived in the Irédé area of Cotonou with her husband and children for about twelve years. The couple take care of the various family expenses together. Simone did not go to school. To meet her various needs, Simone prepares and sells food (a local maize-based dish accompanied by sauce) in Cotonou. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Simone has run this business for fourteen years and has already obtained two loans through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). Simone has repaid all of these credits properly. Faced with her customers' increasing demands, Simone is seeking a third loan, with the goal of strengthening her business and better responding to her customers' requests.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags of maize, peanut oil, and sauce condiments

loans.name: Shanta

texts.en:
Shanta T. is the mother of two sons. Both of her sons are studying in higher secondary school.  Her husband is a farmer.

Mrs. T. is engaged in the cow-raising business. She already owns one cow and she has been selling milk in her area. In Nepal pure and fresh cow’s milk is highly valued for human nutrition. Shanta T. lives in Sainbu-Bhaishapati and in that area the demand for milk is constantly increasing.

She carries her milk containers and sells door-to-door daily in the morning and in the evening.  Because of the rising demand for milk, she wants to buy another cow to increase her production.  Shanta plans to use her loan to purchase a jersey cow which produces more milk than normal cows.

loans.use: to buy another young  cow

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila A. is from the village of Barandias, Pangantucan Bukidnon. She is 47 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Leonila has a sari-sari (variety) store selling both food and daily use products. Leonila has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Leonila joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. Leonila is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Leonila from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family income. 

About HSPFI: HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Adjarath

texts.fr: Née en 1970 à Djougou, dans le Nord du Bénin, I. Adjarath est mariée à DJALO Mamadou et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Adjarath vit depuis une dizaine d'année au quartier Ahoussa à Cotonou, avec son mari et ses enfants. Adjarath n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et contribuer aux charges familiales, Adjarath mène comme activité, la vente de divers produits (sucre en poudre, lait, conserves de sardines, papier hygiéniques, savons, etc.) à son domicile. Adjarath achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Adjarath mène cette activité depuis dix sept ans, et est à son deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Adjarath a bien remboursé son premier prêt. Ce deuxième prêt permettra à Adjarath de renforcer son activité et d'augmenter le stock de ses produits, en vue de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Djougou, in northern Benin, Adjarath I. is married to Mamadou Djalo and is the mother of three children, all in school. Adjarath has lived for about ten years in the Ahoussa area of Cotonou with her husband and children. She never attended school. To meet her needs and provide for the family, Adjarath runs a business selling various products (powdered sugar, milk, canned sardines, toilet paper, soap, etc.) at her house. She buys her products at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Adjarath has run this business for seventeen years, and is on her second loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). She repaid her first loan properly. This second loan will allow her to strengthen her business and increase her stock of merchandise, with the goal of better satisfying her customers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell sugar, canned goods, milk, soap, etc.

loans.name: Mrs. Vanny Earm Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Sampan Leu village in Kandal province there is a village bank loan which consists of twenty-one people. Mrs. Vanny E. is the village bank president, selected by the other members, who will each use a piece of the loan to buy some supplies to support their businesses. Vanny is 47 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Vanthorn Sor, are farmers who own over one-hectare of land to grow crops to support their family. She has two children, one of whom is a beautician in the local village, while the other is attending the local public school. Since her child’s business is going well she wants to expand it. So, Mrs. Vanny E. is seeking a loan to buy some beautician supplies, and the rest of the loan will be used to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy some beautician supplies

loans.name: Katongore Twetungure, Ibanda Group

texts.en:
Hardworking B. Vincent, married with four children of his own to take care of, knows the responsibilities cut out for him. This reality has looked him in the face for the past twenty-three years as he goes about his trivial-round farming business in Mukunguru, Ibanda.

With his minimal 240,000 shillings of earnings a month, Vincent has faced long odds in providing for all his family’s needs, principally his children’s education. He wants to improve on the status quo of his family with the acquisition of this loan; he wants to give his business an improved lease of life in terms of expansion through restocking his farm with more cows and plantations for increased production.

loans.use: To restock his farm wth more cows

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia O. is from the village of Lantay, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 37 years old. Virginia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia runs a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2008, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr: K. Christine est née le 07 Juillet 1976 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Christine est mariée à HOUNKANRIN Achille, un chauffeur. Le couple a cinq enfants à charge, dont trois sont leurs enfants. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Christine s’est installée depuis sept ans à Ekpè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, où elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Christine aide son mari à assurer les différentes charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui génère son activité.  En effet, Christine mène comme activité, la vente de produits vivriers (maïs, haricot, farine de manioc, sucre, pâtes alimentaires, lait, savons, huile d’arachide, etc.) à son domicile. Christine achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Christine exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans.  C’est la première fois que Christine sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, afin de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre aux différentes demandes de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Christine K. was born on 7 July 1976 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Christine is married to Achille Hounkanrin, a driver. The couple have five children in their care, of whom three are their own. Some of the children are in school. Christine moved to Ekpè, in the town of Sèmè-Podji, seven years ago, and currently lives there with her husband and children. She helps her husband provide for the family, thanks to the income generated by her business. Christine runs a business selling various food products (maize, beans, manioc flour, sugar, pasta, milk, soap, peanut oil, etc.) at her house. She buys her products at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Christine has run this business for five years. This is the first time she is seeking a loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), in order to strengthen her business and better respond to the various demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food products (maize, manioc flour, sugar, milk, peanut oil) and soap

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhon Kung Village Bank Group

texts.en: Thirteen people who live in Sampan Leu village in Kandal province make up this village bank loan. They will each use the loan for different purposes that can improve their businesses. All the other members selected Mrs. Sokhon K. as the village bank president. She is 51 years old.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Sokhon K. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline and rice seed, and with the rest of the loan she will rent a plow to plow her field. She is a widow with four children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory. Another sells for a  private company, and the youngest is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, rice seed, and to rent a plow

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina L. is from the village called Barangay Salvacion, in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she sells health and medicinal products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $260 a month from these activities.

In 2008, Rosalina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosalina is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 5th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn P. is from the village of Opol, Misamis Oriental. She is 43 years old. Jocelyn is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Jocelyn run a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, a Kiva parnter. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Moufidath

texts.fr: Née en 1983, A. Moufidath vit depuis treize ans à Sèkandji, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Moufidath est mariée à OROGBO Achime, un transitaire, et est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Moufidath vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple se partage les différentes charges de la famille. Moufidath a très peu fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de sept ans que Moufidath s’est mise à vendre divers produits de mercerie à son domicile. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l’aidant à faire face à ses différents besoins. Moufidath achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Moufidath a obtenu une fois déjà de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien effectué le remboursement. Dans le but d’élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre aux diverses exigences de sa clientèle, Moufidath sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un deuxième prêt.
texts.en:
Born in 1983, Moufidath A. has lived in Sèkandji, in the town of Sèmè-Podji, for thirteen years. Moufidath is married to Achime Orogbo, a shipping agent, and is the mother of one child, who is in school. Moufidath lives together with her child and husband. The couple share the various family expenses between themselves. Moufidath has very little formal schooling. About seven years ago, she began selling various sewing supplies at her house. This business provides her with an income that helps her meet her various needs. Moufidath buys her products at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She has already obtained one loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), and repaid it properly. With the goal of raising the level of her business and better responding to the various needs of her customers, Moufidath is seeking a second loan through ALIDÉ.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a 43 year-old goat seller. She buys and sells goats in a commercial market area. She has been in this business for two years. Nancy is married and has two children, a boy and a girl, who are 20 and 25 years old. 

The primary challenges that she faces are competition from other sellers. In addition to goat selling, Nancy also sells sugar, maize, beans, tea, and flour.  Before goat selling, she worked at a retail shop.

Nancy plans to use the 20,000 KES loan to buy more goats to be able to sell more for higher income.

In the future, Nancy hopes to educate her children, train them in business, and build a permanent home.  In five years, she dreams of purchasing a vehicle to transport goats so that she can become a wholesaler.

Nancy describes herself as jovial, hardworking, persistent, and patient.

loans.use: To buy more goats to be able to sell more for higher income

Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Adinkpo

texts.fr: ADINKPO J. est né le 22 Juin 1987 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. J. vit depuis vingt deux ans au quartier Dégo à Cotonou. Marié à GBESSOE Angèle, une coiffeuse, J. a trois enfants à charge, dont un est son enfant. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. J. vit ensemble avec sa femme et ses enfants. Le couple se partage ensemble les différentes charges familiales. J. a très peu fréquenté l’école, mais a appris le métier d’électricien bâtiment. A côté, J. vend divers matériels électriques (multiprise, fils électriques, ampoules, tuyaux, prises,etc.) de façon ambulante. J. exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans. C’est la première fois que J. sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue de renforcer son activité et d’accroître sa clientèle.
texts.en:
J. Adinkpo was born on 22 June 1987 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. He has lived in the Dégo area of Cotonou for twenty years. Married to Angèle Gbessoe, a hairdresser, J. has three children in his care, of whom one is his own. All of the children are in school. J. lives together with his wife and children. The couple share the various family expenses between themselves. J. had very little formal schooling, but trained to be a building electrician. On the side, J. sells various electrical supplies (power strips, electrical wiring, light bulbs, pipes, outlets, etc.) door-to-door. He has run this business for five years. This is the first time he is seeking a loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), with the goal of strengthening his business and enlarging his clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electrical supplies (electrical wiring, switches, power strips, light bulbs, etc.)

Helen has been involved in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month.

In 2010, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

texts.en: Forty-nine-year-old Perlita V. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Perlita raises crops. In February 2010, Perlita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perlita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, crude oil for the tractor and cloth for sewing. This will be the second loan taken out by Perlita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve it. texts.en:
K. Ruth is 48 years old, married, and blessed with eight children, two of whom go to school. She also takes care of three dependants, who are in school, too.
Ruth is a hardworking businesswoman who has operated a retail shop business for over four years. She is using her loan to purchase retail items such as salt, maize flour, cooking oil, paraffin and so forth, for resale in her shop. She is an inspiring businesswoman whose dream is to work hard for the welfare of her family.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as salt, maize flour, cooking oil, paraffin, etc.

loans.name: Zinsou Francis

texts.fr: Né en 1967 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, B. Zinsou Francis vit depuis trente ans au quartier Akpokpota à Cotonou. Francis est marié à ATCHEDEDJI Marie et est père de six enfants, dont cinq sont à sa charge. Seulement certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Francis vit ensemble avec sa femme et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges de la maison. Francis a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Francis exerce le métier d’électricien bâtiment. Parallèlement, Francis vend des matériels électriques (fils électriques, ampoules, multiprises, etc.) de façon ambulante. C’est à Cotonou que Francis achète ses produits. Dans le but d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle, Francis sollicite pour une première fois, de prêt à ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1967 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Mr. B. Zinsou Francis has lived for thirty years in the Akpokpota district in Cotonou. He is married to Ms. ATCHEDEDJI Marie and is the father of six children. Only some of his children have had schooling. He lives together with his wife and children. The couple jointly ensure that their different household expenses are covered. Francis had dropped out of middle school. He has been a building electrician for a dozen years. Concurrently, he sells electrical supplies and equipment (electrical wire, light bulbs, power strips, etc.) door-to-door. He gets his supplies in Cotonou. With the goal of increasing his stock of goods and responding better to customer requirements, Francis is requesting a loan from ALIDé for the first time.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying electrical supplies and equipment

loans.name: Dansou Michel

texts.fr: Né en 1974 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, A. Dansou Michel vit depuis trente six ans environs au quartier Agbalilamè à Cotonou. Marié à DOSSA Clémence, une ménagère, Michel est père de trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Michel a en plus de ses enfants, un autre enfant à sa charge. Michel vit ensemble avec sa femme et ses enfants. Le couple subvient ensemble aux divers besoins de la famille. Michel n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Il y a près de quatre ans que Michel exerce l’activité d’électricien bâtiment. Parallèlement, Michel vend de façon ambulante des matériels électriques (interrupteurs, fils électriques, tuyaux, ampoules, etc.). C’est la première fois que Michel sollicite un concours financier de ALIDé, en vue d’élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle. Michel ambitionne plus tard ouvrir une boutique pour y vendre ses produits.
texts.en:
Born in 1974 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Mr. A. Dansou Michel has been living for 36 years in the Agbalilamè district in Cotonou. Married to Ms. DOSSA Clémence, a housewife, he is the father of three children, who are all in school. He also has another child to support aside from his own. Michel lives together with his wife and children. The couple jointly cover their various family expenses. Michel did not attend primary school. For nearly four years, he has work as a building electrician. Concurrently, he goes door-to-door selling electrical supplies and equipment (circuit breakers, electrical wire, conduit, light bulbs, etc.) This is the first time that Michel has requested financial assistance from ALIDé for raising his level of business and satisfying his customers. His ambition for the future is to open a store in which to sell his goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying electrical supplies and equipment

loans.name: M. Paulin

texts.fr: H. M. Paulin est né le 19 Novembre 1987 à Kétonou au Bénin. Marié à MOUSSA Nafissatou, une couturière, Paulin est père de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Paulin vit avec sa famille depuis neuf ans, à Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji. Les charges de la famille sont supportées par le couple. Paulin n’a pas fréquenté l’école, mais a appris le métier d’électricien bâtiment. C’est cette activité que Paulin mène depuis quatre ans, et qui lui permet de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. A côté, Paulin vend de façon ambulante, des matériels électriques (fils, interrupteurs, multiprises, etc.). Dans le but de renforcer son fonds de roulement et d’augmenter le stock de ses produits,  Paulin sollicite pour une première fois, l’appui financier de ALIDé. Paulin envisage prochainement, ouvrir une boutique pour vendre ses produits.
texts.en:
Mr. H. M. Paulin was born on November 19, 1987 in Kétonou, Benin. Married to Ms. MOUSSA Nafissatou, a seamstress, he is the father of three children, who are all in school. He has lived with his family for nine years in Lokokoukoumè, in the community of Sèmè-Podji. Family expenses are covered by the couple. Paulin did not attend school, but he learned the trade of building electrician that he has work at for four years. It allows him to provide for his family. On the side, he sells electrical supplies and equipment (wire, circuit breakers, power strips, etc.) door-to-door. With the goal of bolstering his working capital and increasing his inventory, Paulin is requesting financial support from ALIDé for the first time. He envisions opening a store soon to sell his products.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying electrical supplies and equipment

loans.name: Phidelis

texts.en:
Phidelis is a 30 year-old welder. He primarily does welding of doors and windows. He has been in this business for 2 years. Phidelis is married and has 2 children, 1 boy and 1 girl, aged between 3 and 6 years old. The primary challenges that he faces are competition from other welders and electricity outages. In addition to welding, Phidelis also does farming at home and keeps cattle and sheep. Before welding, he worked at a shop.

Phidelis plans to use the 80,000 KES loan to to purchase welding materials. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 KES.

In the future, Phidelis hopes to supply welding materials as a wholesaler from his home. In 5 years, he dreams of generating an income of at least 150,000 KES.

Phidelis describes himself as outgoing, friendly, and focused.

loans.use: To purchase welding materials.

loans.name: Mrs. Thy Moel Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fifteen people make up this village bank loA. located in SampA. Leu village in Kandal province. Mrs. Thy M. is village bank president, selected by the others members who will each use a piece of the loA. for different purposes. She was born in 1958. She and her husband, Mr. Sung Ley Kuy, are farmers who own a small piece of land and grow crops to sell to support their family's living. Now her problem is that her crop field has infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. To improve production, Mrs. Thy M. is asking for a loA. to buy fertilizer and pesticide. With this activity, the couple supports four children, one of whom is a healer, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Félicité

texts.fr: T. Félicité est née le 05 Juin 1960 à Adjohoun, dans le département de l’Ouémé. Félicité est mariée à DEMANGNON Marc et est mère de deux enfants.  Le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge. Félicité vit avec sa famille, au quartier Danmin dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis six ans. Félicité vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Félicité n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a près de dix huit ans que Félicité prépare et vend du « agbéli » (aliment local fait à base de maïs, accompagné de sauce). De façon secondaire, Félicité vend également en détail, du maïs et de l’huile d’arachide. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Félicité achète ses produits. Face à la demande de plus en plus importante de sa clientèle, Félicité voudrait augmenter son stock de produit, et par ricochet sa production, afin de mieux faire face aux exigences de sa clientèle. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter pour la première fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Félicité T. was born on June 5, 1960 in Adjohoun, in the Ouémé Department of Benin. Félicité is married to Marc DEMANGNON and is a mother of two. The couple also looks after another child. Félicité has lived with her family in the Danmin neighbourhood in the Sèmè-Podji township for six years.
Félicité helps her husband cover the family expenses. Félicité did not attend school, but for almost 18 years, Félicité has prepared and sold “agbéli” (a local corn-based dish served with sauce). Félicité also sells corn and peanut oil on the side. Félicité buys her products in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.
Facing increasing customer demand, Félicité would like to increase her stock, and in turn her production, in order to better meet the needs of her customers. This is why she is requesting her first loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn and oil

loans.name: Béti

texts.fr: Née en 1958 à Djeffa au Bénin, H. Béti est mariée à HOUESSOU Gbétodé, un cultivateur. Le couple a huit enfants, dont quatre sont à leur charge. Seulement certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Il y a près de quinze ans que Béti s’est installée avec son mari au quartier Gomin, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji.  La famille vit ensemble et le couple se partage les différentes charges familiales. Béti n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour se prendre en charge, Béti fait la transformation du manioc en farine de manioc à son domicile et vend ensuite son produit fini à sa clientèle. Béti achète ses matières premières à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est la première fois que Béti sollicite l’aide financier de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter son stock de produits et de se faire plus de revenus.
texts.en:
Born in 1958 in Djeffa, in Benin, Ms. H. Béti is married to Mr. HOUESSOU Gbétodé, a farmer.  The couple have eight children, of whom four are in their care.  Only some of the children have had schooling.  For almost fifteen years, Béti has been living in the Gomin district, in the community of Sèmè-Podji.  The family lives together, and the couple share in covering their different family expenses.  Béti did not attend school.  To support herself, she processes cassava tubers into cassava flour in her home and then sells her finished product to her customers.  She purchases her ingredients in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. This is the first time that Béti has requested financial aid from ALIDé in order to increase her inventory and to bring in more income.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cassava

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel is a 24 year-old "boda boda" driver. He provides transport services on his motorbike along the Nairobi Highway between Thika and Niarobi. He carries many kind of passengers: men, women, and children. He has been in this business for 2 years. The primary challenges that he faces are the high cost of maintenance and providing spare parts for his motorbike.  Before becoming a boda boda driver, Joel sold items at a kiosk that he owned.

Joel plans to use his 20,000 KES loan to purchase a more modern motorbike so that he can expand his business. In the future, Joel hopes to "graduate" from the motorbike transport business to a taxi business with a car. In 5 years, he sees himself as a successful businessman with a fleet of cars on the road.

Joel describes himself as hard-working, able to work long hours, and a good investor of the the little money that he has.

loans.use: To buy a more modern motorbike to expand his business.

loans.name: Bulowooza B Mitti Mwajuma Group

texts.en: M. Mwajuma is a business lady of twenty-nine years old. She is married and has three children, all in schooling. She is also taking care of four dependents who are in schooling too. She deals in the timber business. She has stayed in this business for over ten years. She is using the loan to purchase timber at market. The loan is adding capital into her business as well expanding the business. She is a promising business lady whose dream is to educate her children to the University level.

loans.use: To purchase timber at market.

loans.name: Milka

texts.en:
Milka is a 49 year-old provider of photocopying and secretarial services. She offers typing, stationery, photography, and photocopying services to business people and students in a shop on a busy street. She has been in this business for 7 years. Milka is single and has 2 children. 

The primary challenges that she faces are the breakdown of photocopiers. Before offering secretarial services, she worked in a salon. Milka plans to use the 80,000 KES loan to purchase a photocopy machine. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 KES.

In the future, Milka hopes to buy land nearby where she can build a home. In 5 years, she dreams of opening a studio and a bookshop. Milka describes herself as motherly and a visionary.

loans.use: To purchase a photocopy machine.

loans.name: Melina

texts.en:
Melina O. is from the village of Camarahan Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 51 years old. Melina is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Melina owns & operates a seafood products business, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Melina has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Melina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Melina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Melina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Mrs. Son Chhith Village Bank Group

texts.en: Son C., 66, is a village bank president and leader of this group loan. A total of sixteen people make up the group from Sampan Leu village in Kandal province.  They will each use a piece of the loan for different purposes.  Son is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows crops to sell to support her family.  Her one child is a beautician and she would like to help her daughter expand her business.  Son is seeking for a loan to buy beautician supplies.

loans.use: Buy beautician supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tea leaves to expand into wholesale business.

loans.name: Nangali Mwajuma Kirunda Group

texts.en: Mwajuma K. is a hardworking business woman of fifty years old. She is married and has two children. One child is in schooling. She is looking after five dependents (orphans) who are also in schooling. She has been running a restaurant business for twenty years so far. She is using the loan to purchase a variety of food (bananas, posho, sweet potatoes, beans, meat, chicken, cassava, and so forth) and other requirements, like charcoal and so forth, for her restaurant business. She is an encouraging business woman whose dreams are to purchase a car, educate her children and to construct rental houses.

loans.use: To purchase variety of food and other requirements for her restaurant business.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria A. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. She is 59 years old. Victoria is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Victoria owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Victoria has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Victoria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Victoria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Victoria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Heng Kith Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has fifteen people who live in Sampan Leu village in Kandal province.  Heng K. is the village bank president, selected by the other members.  Each will use a piece of the loan for different purposes.  She and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land to grow crops to sell to support their family.  Their field is infertile and it is far away from an irrigation system.  So to improve production, Heng is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline and to cover the cost of renting a machine to plow her field.  She is a mother of four children, two of whom are employed in a casino club.  Another is a cane seller.  The youngest attends a local public school.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, gasoline and rent a plow.

loans.name: Chanthou's Group

texts.en: In Chher Teal I village, in Kandal province consists five people who make up this group loan.  Chanthou M., 23, is its leader.  Members will use a piece of the loan for different purposes.  Chanthou is a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land to grow crops to sell to support her family.  Her problem is that her field is far away from an irrigation system.  So to improve production, Chanthou is applying for a loan to buy a water machine.  Her husband is a fisherman who can earn some money by selling fish.  They have two young childR..

loans.use: Buy a water machine.

loans.name: Lakham

texts.en:
Lakham is a 35 year-old clothes seller. He sells second-hand clothes to people in a local marketplace. He has been in this business for 2 years. Lakham is married and has a 3 year-old son. The primary challenges that he faces are getting capital and building a stall for sales. In addition to selling clothes, Lakham also sells tea leaves and bananas. 

Lakham plans to use the 40,000 KES loan to purchase more clothing inventory to sell. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 KES. In the future, Lakham hopes to get a permanent selling location and to buy a wider variety of goods. In 5 years, he dreams of developing his business and getting his own shop on land that he owns.

Lakham describes himself as hardworking, optimistic, and business-minded.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing stock to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Sinoeun Soy Village Bank Group

texts.en: Nine people from Preaek Anhchanh village, in Kandal province make up this group loan.  Each member will use a piece of the loan to improve their own business. Sinoeun S., who is a vegetable seller is the group's president.  She wants to expand her business and requests a loan to buy more vegetable for resell.  Her husband is a taxi driver who owns a car and his profits help to support his family.  They have three children; one helps out by selling vegetables.  The other two attend a local public school.

loans.use: Buy more vegetable for resell.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
For a time span of ten years, N. Edgar from Kitongore, Ibanda, has been running a multipurpose business that includes stationery, agriculture, and the sale of matooke (plantain). With his good management and customer care skills, these businesses generate him a profit of 200,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis.

Edgar looks forward to improving his banana plantation through mulching and spraying the pests that are currently disorganizing his returns. This will definitely give his ventures a new lease of life for some time. This loan will contribute to the purchase of pesticides and mulches and also enable him to restock his stationery store with more reams of paper and toner for printing.

Edgar’s motive is to earn money to pay his children’s school fees and also to expand his businesses for more income.

loans.use: To buy mulches and pesticides for his plantation and reams of paper and toner for his store

loans.name: Mame Diarra Bousso

texts.fr: Madame Mame Diarra Bousso Ndiayeest commerçante de chaussures, sacs et autres depuis 1989.  Elle s'approvisionne en république de la Gambie et place ses produits à ses clients qui réglent à la fi de chaque mois. Cette femme divorcée compte sur son seul business pour satisfaire ses besoins. Elle souhaitait cependant un prêt de 150 000 FCFA pour mener à bien ses activités.
texts.en:
Madam Mame Diarra Bousso N. has been trading in shoes,bags and other items since 1989. She gets her supplies from the Republic of Gambia and gives her products to her customers who pay at the end of the month. This divorced woman counts on her only business to meet her needs. She wants a loan of 150 000FCFA to operate well her business.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get her supplies

loans.name: Shakira

texts.en: This young lady sells cereals, vegetables, and other products from her home in Togo. She is 23 years old and has been working in this business for about two years. She is married and she and her husband have one child. She has requested a loan of 500,000 XOF from WAGES to purchase maize, millet, sorghum, flour, and other foods and ingredients to sell in her stall. This is her first loan request with WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase cereals

loans.name: Pesei's Group

texts.en: This group loan has four members who are located in Lekh Muoy village, in Kandal province.  Pesei N. is the group's leader, selected by the other members.  Each will use a piece of the loan for different purposes.  Pesei is married with two school-age children.  She is a seamstress in garment factory and earns a low wage. Her husband is a policeman and his income also supports their family.  To improve their living conditions, Pesei is seeking a loan to buy a plot of land to grow crops.

loans.use: Buy a plot of land.

loans.name: Tsevel

texts.en:
Tsevel is 38 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent). She has one daughter and two sons; two of the children are in secondary school and one is in kindergarten. The family has been living together in their current home for six years.

Tsevel operates a vegetable trading business at the local market with the help of her husband. She has been operating her business since 1990, and has steadily expanded it over the years. Tsevel used to purchase the vegetables she sells, but in 2009, she started growing the vegetables herself. She has a large 20-ton capacity warehouse in which she stores her products. Using her business profits, Tsevel purchased a plot of land for growing vegetables and a separate plot with a yard for her family. Tsevel is an open person and says, “Last year I planted vegetables on other people's land. Now I have my own land for my business. This will help my business and increase my earnings.” Tsevel is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan for this season's planting expenses.

loans.use: planting expenses

loans.name: Wenefrida

texts.en:
Wenefrida A. is from the village of Mibantang, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 56 years old, married and has 7 adult-aged children. Wenefrida owns and operates a food stall, selling a variety of food products in the local community. Wenefrida has been involved in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Wenefrida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wenefrida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase additional materials needed in her food stall, such as food containers and plates. Wenefrida is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Wenefrida from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria P. is from the village of Kiburiao, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 59 years old, married and has 5 adult-aged children. Gloria owns and operates a food stall, primarily selling soft drinks, snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Gloria has been involved in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Gloria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Gloria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en: John K. W. is 28 years old, married and has one child aged two years. For the last seven years, he has been involved in a transport business in a residential area in Thika. He says the business is good; the only major challenge is that during the rainy seasons he is unable to do much business since the bad roads make some areas inaccessible. He is using his loan of KES 50,000 to buy another motorcycle to expand his business. In the future, he hopes to have another child and to give his children quality education. He also plans to buy a matatu (a share taxi) and a plot of land and build rental houses. He describes himself as cheerful, hardworking and very patient.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Abalo

texts.en: Abalo M. has requested a loan of 500,000 CFA to purchase 17 sacks of corn for his cereal selling business. He has worked selling corn and other grains for about 11 years. Abalo is 44 years old and married to another entrepreneur. He and his wife have four children. This is his first microloan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase corn for resale.

loans.name: Kenedy

texts.en:
Kenedy is a 38 year-old electronics repairman. For the past 11 years, he has serviced and repaired electronics at a shop next to the main road in a very populated area. Kenedy is married and has five children, four boys and one girl, between the ages of 1 and 13 years old. The primary business challenge he faces is unpredictable power blackouts. 

Kenedy plans to use the 80,000 KES loan to purchase equipment, tools, and parts for electronic repairs such as voltmeters, adapters, power screwdrivers and protective screens. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 50,000 KES. In the future, Kenedy hopes to further expand his business. In five years, he dreams of owning a shop to sell electrical equipment. Kenedy describes himself as intelligent.

loans.use: To purchase equipment, tools, and parts for electronic repairs.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda C. is from the village of Salawagan, Quezon Bukidnon. She is 53 years old, married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2007, Rosalinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used as working capital and to purchase additional inventory. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Rosalinda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Euphrasie

texts.fr: N. Euphrasie est née en 1985 à Adjohoun, dans le département de l’Ouémé. Euphrasie est mariée à HODONOU Julien, un chauffeur. Le couple a trois enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. La famille vit à PK10- Enafa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis une dizaine d’année. Euphrasie subvient avec son mari aux différents besoins de la famille. Euphrasie n’a pas fréquenté l’école.
